Life at the X-Mansion had been different for him. He was used to sneaking and hiding, killing and hurting; not normal things like playing games and chatting. Heck, he wasn't used to friends either. That could account for his poor social skills, perhaps. He had no problem talking with people, meaning he wasn't shy. Far from it, the opposite was true. Some at the mansion, like Bobby Drake, found Logan's way of life to be ideal. Others, like Scott Summers, saw Logan as a lost cause and a nuisance to him and all of existence. Logan didn't care either way. If people liked him, they liked him, if they didn't, they didn't. He wasn't in the business of changing minds; that is, unless killing them counted.

Xavier had helped some, but for the most part he emphasized that Logan would have to recover the lost memories of his past on his own - aggravating Logan considerably. He stayed for a few reasons. The first being that he didn't really have anywhere else to go. Logan was also helping Ororo and the students at the mansion, carrying on where Xavier, Jean, and Scott had left off, and he enjoyed it too.
